question: Consider the identity function $I_N : \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ defined as $I_N (x) = x \ \forall x \in \mathbb{N}$. Show that although $I_N$ is onto but $I_N + I_N : \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$ defined as $(I_N + I_N) (x) = I_N (x) + I_N (x) = x + x = 2x$ is not onto.
solution:
Clearly $I_N$ is onto.

But $I_N + I_N$ is not onto, as we can find an element $3$ in the co-domain $\mathbb{N}$ such that there does not exist any $x$ in the domain $\mathbb{N}$ with $(I_N + I_N) (x) = 2x = 3$.
